p: It is possible that when one plant–pollinator interaction is lost through a spatial or temporal mismatch, a new interaction will take its place. For example, Alarcón et al. (2008) found that a plant–pollinator network changed its topology year-by-year due to changes in climate, as well as other factors. Similarly, novel interactions accounted for almost half of the interactions remaining in sites resampled more than a century later by Burkle et al. (2013); however, these novel interactions can entail reduced pollinator fidelity and effectiveness ( Burkle et al., 2013). Thus, data on fitness components such as pollen deposition and seed set may be needed to determine the plant reproductive consequences of novel interactions and potential mismatches.
